name: double-bass
definition: The largest bowed stringed instrument in the modern orchestra, also used frequently in jazz ensembles, especially played pizzicato.
description:
The double bass is the largest and lowest-pitched bowed string instrument in the modern symphony orchestra.

The double bass, usually considered a member of the violin family, has the sloping shoulders and flat back characteristic of the viols.

It is typically constructed from several types of wood, including maple for the back, spruce for the top, and ebony for the fingerboard.

The double bass is played either with a bow - arco or by plucking the strings - pizzicato. In orchestral repertoire and tango music, both arco and pizzicato are employed.

Player stands, or sits on a high stool, and leans the instrument against their body, turned slightly inward to put the strings comfortably in reach.

The double bass is a standard member of the orchestra's string section, as well as the concert band and is featured in concertos, solo and chamber music in Western classical music.

It is also used in jazz bands, rockabilly bands, bluegrass music, and some country music bands.

facts.name: Usually considered part of violin family
facts.value: It is uncertain whether the instrument is a descendant of the viola da gamba or of the violin, but it is traditionally aligned with the violin family.

facts.name: Many different bow articulations
facts.value: Classical bass students learn all of the different bow articulations used by other string section players such as détaché, legato, staccato, sforzato, martelé, sul ponticello, sul tasto, tremolo, spiccato and sautillé.

facts.name: Produce a meancing effect
facts.value: Bowed notes in the lowest register of the instrument produce a dark, heavy, mighty, or even menacing effect, when played with a fortissimo dynamic.

facts.name: The fingerboard is made of ebony
facts.value: The fingerboard is made of ebony on high-quality instruments; on less expensive student instruments, other woods may be used and then painted or stained black - a process called 'ebonizing'.

facts.name: It is a tall instrument
facts.value: The double bass stands around 180 cm from scroll to endpin. However, other sizes are available to accommodate a player's height and hand size.

facts.name: Low piches are played with no vibrato
facts.value: In general, very loud, low-register passages are played with little or no vibrato, as the main goal with low pitches is to provide a clear fundamental bass for the string section.

facts.name: Classical players use vibrato
facts.value: Classical players use vibrato, an effect created by rocking or quivering the left hand finger that is contacting the string, which then transfers an undulation in pitch to the tone.

facts.name: It plays the bass line
facts.value: It plays low-pitched musical notes in musical ensembles and bands. In jazz bands, these low-pitched musical notes are called the 'bass line'.

facts.name: Jazz professionals pizzicato is difficult
facts.value: Pizzicato basslines performed by leading jazz professionals are much more difficult than the pizzicato basslines that Classical bassists encounter in the standard orchestral literature.

facts.name: In jazz pizzicato is the norm
facts.value: In orchestral repertoire and tango music, both arco and pizzicato are employed. In jazz, blues, and rockabilly, pizzicato is the norm.
